data.title: ‚ÄúCartel Don‚Äôt Kill Surfers‚Äù, A Gringo‚Äôs Guide To Northern Baja California, Mexico
data.meta_description: On my Baja surf trips I've been robbed at gunpoint, forced to pay bribes, met felons on the run, had cars broken into, and have been lost more times than I wish to remember.
data.text:
Baja California, a surfer‚Äôs paradise‚Ä¶ During my adventures south of the border I‚Äôve been robbed at gunpoint, forced to pay bribes, met felons on the run, had cars broken into, and have been lost more times than I wish to remember.

My name is Justin Gregory, I‚Äôm a surfer living in San Diego, California and over the year‚Äôs I‚Äôve made more trips than I can count to the holy land of rights known as Northern Baja California, Mexico.

After everything I‚Äôve been through, why the hell would someone like me keep coming back to a place like this?

Well, when I wasn‚Äôt out sniffing for trouble, I‚Äôve scored perfect waves without a soul in sight, been welcomed by locals, stuffed my face with amazing food, met incredible friends, and in an interesting situation, had the owner of a bar trust me with the key to close down in exchange for a free hotel room.

Despite my extensive knowledge and experience traveling south of the border, I‚Äôve always pictured myself as the LAST person to write the go-to guide on surfing northern Baja California, Mexico.

The truth is, even though I‚Äôm a harsh critic on how the media portrays Mexico I also do appreciate the fact that it has successfully deterred so many people from going down there.

‚ÄúThe old me‚Äù would have told you I support building a border wall if it was to keep California surfers away from my favorite, empty surf spots.

However, after so many years of traveling to Baja and leaving with memories to last a lifetime, I‚Äôve come to the realization that my appreciation for such an amazing place would not be real unless I share the valuable things I‚Äôve learned for other people to implement themselves.

In addition to this, over the years I‚Äôve learned a lot of things that other people who are looking to explore Baja simply NEED TO UNDERSTAND. Not knowing what to expect or how to conduct yourself (especially in dangerous scenarios) will not only put you in a bad position but could possibly get you killed.

Don‚Äôt be fooled, I‚Äôm no saint. Many of the lessons you‚Äôll receive in this guide came from me learning things the HARD way. I‚Äôve just gotten lucky a time or two‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll explain later.

Before We Begin, Let Me Make Something Clear

If you‚Äôre looking for a travel itinerary with a list of my favorite surf spots, you‚Äôre in the wrong place amigo/amiga. The last thing I want next time I head down south is to wonder, ‚Äúwho‚Äôs the asshole that told everyone about this place?‚Äù‚Ä¶ Only to find out it‚Äôs ME.

Long story short, I‚Äôm not about to have the surfing community put a bounty on my head.

Let me preface this with the truth; you don‚Äôt need anyone to tell you where to surf. Anyone with internet connection can pull a map on Surfline and check every mainstream spot anyways.

However, I‚Äôm here to tell you that you shouldn‚Äôt even do that. There‚Äôs a better way. You‚Äôll have more fun, experience twice the adventure, and you very well might find the best wave of your life.

Stick with me here because I‚Äôm about to break it ALL down for you.

We‚Äôre going to cover:

Reasons Why You SHOULDN‚ÄôT Go To Mexico

What To Bring and What To Leave at Home

If You Should or Shouldn‚Äôt Drive Your Car (plus some things you NEED to know if you do)

A Firsthand Story On How You SHOULD NOT Handle Corrupt Police Officers

Modern Realities and New Dangers in Baja

Is Camping in Baja Safe?

Are The Cartels REALLY That Dangerous?

How To Get yourself Out Of a Pinch

Best Places To Eat

Quality of Surf and What To Expect

How To Find a Place to Sleep

Lifesaving Tips on Making It Back To The United States Without Spending a Lifetime At The border

Disclaimer: This isn‚Äôt the ‚Äúcall your buddy for some recommendations‚Äù type of guide, nor is it a ‚Äútop ten things to do in Baja‚Äù with a bunch of unnecessary fluff. What you‚Äôre about to read is everything I‚Äôve learned after YEARS of surfing Northern Baja. You won‚Äôt find this anywhere else. There‚Äôs nothing in here that you DON‚ÄôT need to know however, we left out NOTHING you do need to know.

Scared Of Mexico? Here‚Äôs Why You Should STAY Home (Read Carefully)

Because of the political unrest many people view Mexico as this dangerous and lawless place where being a foreigner puts a target on your back. Here‚Äôs the thing, I don‚Äôt blame them. For the longest time I‚Äôve been victim to this school of thought as well.

This was until I spent a day in Tijuana with my friend Cecilia who was born in Mexico and grew up in Tijuana. Her father was an attorney who held political influence in the city and from a young age Cecilia was exposed to the realities of how the system runs down there.

I was just a wee little lad during this time, not much older than seventeen, and while spending the day with her I took the opportunity to pick her brain.

She never excused the violence from the cartels or downplayed the fact that cops like to take advantage of naive, drunk tourists. She acknowledged these facts however, she also told me something that I never forgot.

She said, ‚ÄúComing down to Mexico, you must understand that if you‚Äôre looking for trouble, you WILL find it. Trouble will find you. But if you‚Äôre responsible, Mexico will treat you like a king.‚Äù.

Reflecting on this years later, after dozens of Mexico trips under my belt, I can tell you there has never been a more accurate statement.

But let‚Äôs define what ‚Äúlooking for trouble‚Äù means because some of you are looking for trouble without even knowing it.

Looking for trouble could mean BREAKING THE LAW (the laws aren‚Äôt always the same down here), DRAWING NEGATIVE ATTENTION TO YOURSELF, or even any attention to yourself for that matter, and being BLINDLY NAIVE.

There‚Äôs a reason United States security personnel and military members get a briefing every time they enter a new country. Once you cross that line you enter a new world with different rules, cultures, expectations, and most of all, consequences. If you don‚Äôt know already, you‚Äôll understand later why I‚Äôm so serious about some of these things.

Thankfully, Mexico isn‚Äôt as dangerous the other countries our service members enter into and 95% of the things you need to know will be included in the rest of this article.

Every time, and I mean EVERY TIME I‚Äôve had issues in Baja it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve been doing things I shouldn‚Äôt have (often without knowing).

Understanding this philosophy will take you along way. It will also force you to look at the frequent horror stories with a different perspective.

If you‚Äôre the type of person who turns a normal night out into a scene out of the movie The Hangover, I commend you. However, you‚Äôre entering Mexico at your own risk.

You may wake up face down in a cockfighting ring, with no wallet, no phone, wondering what happened to your friends‚Ä¶ Don‚Äôt ask. Or worse, you‚Äôll make yourself a target for desperate people who are looking to take advantage of your stupidity.

Being out VERY late at night, getting sloppy drunk, flashing your cash, buying cocaine, or forcing yourself on the wrong guys girlfriend is a good way to accomplish one of thee things:

Make for a good story

Get yourself into a sketchy situation

Worst case scenario, make you the ‚Äúvictim‚Äù in the next tragic headline we read about

If you‚Äôre a hot head that doesn‚Äôt back down from a fight, finds themselves getting into arguments, is unwilling to let little shit slide, can‚Äôt handle your alcohol, or resorts to violence, you SHOULDN‚ÄôT come to Baja.

If you can‚Äôt or are unwilling to adapt your behaviors in order to respect other cultures, if you are too lazy/naive to learn about the realities of where you‚Äôre going, you probably SHOULDN‚ÄôT come to Baja.

If you‚Äôre the type of person that relies on others to solve your problems, bail you out, or if you‚Äôre simply not resourceful, either travel with people that are or perhaps think twice about traveling to Baja.

For the rest of you, the holy land awaits.

Baja Essentials: What To Bring & What to LEAVE at Home

We all have different travel styles. Before a trip some people like to make detailed lists and check them twice. They bring two of everything and pack a lunch. Other people barely bring their wallets and leave home with two left shoes.

Packing for Baja should NOT be a stressful experience, don‚Äôt overthink it. Everything you could ever want or need is already down there. Instead of worrying about what to bring, focus on what you SHOULDN‚ÄôT bring.

Bring a Passport. I know, obviously. But hey, I‚Äôve seen people do dumb things so I‚Äôm not leaving it out. Ironically, I‚Äôve often used an enhanced drivers license which does the trick for Mexico and Canada.

They do not check documents when entering Mexico, its coming back into the states where you need to have your information ready. No need getting anxious on your way in.

Bring cash. In a place like Mexico everything is for sale and everything is negotiable. Cash is King. For a day trip I like to bring around $200. If you‚Äôre spending 24 hours in Baja, you can definitely have a great time for under $200.

It‚Äôs always nice to have a little emergency cash in case of a pinch (I‚Äôll explain soon). As a friend once said to me, ‚Äú$20 moves mountains down here‚Äù.

Bring cash, a credit card or two, but I always suggest leaving your debit cards home. In the event your wallet is stolen, a shady shop owner secretly charges you five times the price than what they told you, or you get escorted to an ATM by a corrupt police officer or thief, credit card companies are much easier to work with when applying for chargebacks on false charges or scams.

Getting your debit card swiped can be a much more stressful process when trying to retrieve lost funds. Credit cards are safe at most restaurants and stores, I‚Äôve used my AMEX card countless times without any issues and recommend using a card similar to mine, which doesn‚Äôt add on international charges.

Pro Tip: I never use the ATM‚Äôs in Mexico unless I absolutely have to. Their service fees are surprisingly expensive and unless you can read Spanish it is a super difficult process, especially after a few Pacificos. I‚Äôve seen friends get charged a $10 service fee only to pull out $15 by mistake because of the language barrier. Without failure, I stop at a 7/11 in San Diego and use their ATM to grab cash on my way out of town.üëçüèº

Bring a full tank of gas ‚Äì Mexican gas stations have cheap gas by the liter but when I‚Äôve filled my tank down there I‚Äôve noticed my car doesn‚Äôt perform as well. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs not a huge deal, especially if you have a classic surf wagon like a Toyota that can run on salt water.

I prefer to fill up in the states but if I need to top off while in Mexico I make sure to buy their premium gasoline.

Non essential items I like to bring (apart from the obvious surf gear):

Spare car key

Extra set of clothes in case I get dirty, or decide to stay an extra night

Second form of ID in addition to passport or enhanced drivers license

Tool kit

Jumper cables

Headlamp

Ding repair kit

Machete/Hatchet if I camp, along with other overnight gear

Also, many people advocate for getting Mexican Insurance on your car before driving down. I‚Äôm not a saint and I‚Äôve often drove down without it (but I‚Äôve also made some stupid mistakes in my lifetime). This being said I highly recommend getting a temporary international insurance plan, especially if you plan for an epic long distance adventure. Getting into a car wreck down south can be a nightmare, the least thing you can do is have a fallback.

As obvious as it may sound, do NOT, under any circumstances, bring drugs or firearms into Mexico. These are highly illegal and you WILL get thrown the hammer if caught. So unless you want to get your cheeks clapped in a dirty TJ jail, leave your second amendment home.

Below I‚Äôve included a section on the currency exchange and a breakdown of costs so you can calculate how much moolah you‚Äôll need.

Keep in mind Mexico is like Vegas. Rarely will you ever leave that place with cash. Whatever you bring, expect it to magically disappear.

On more than one occasion, my extra ‚Äúemergency‚Äù funds turned into ‚Äúmore beers, more tacos‚Äù money.

Affordability

Keep in mind, while paying in cash with US dollars, you will be given your change in pesos. The current exchange rate is $1 USD = $18 Mexican Pesos. I, along with most people round up to $1 : $20 to make the math easier.

Pro Tip: When given change, it‚Äôs decent practice to count it discreetly just to make sure the person you‚Äôre dealing with didn‚Äôt pull a fast one. This mainly applies when buying things from street vendors and small markets.

Here‚Äôs a rough breakdown on what prices look like in Mexico for common items you can expect to purchase during your trip :

Six pack of domestic beer: $5 USD

Gas: $4 USD / Gallon

Lobster dinner in Puerto Nuevo: $25 USD

Plate of street tacos: $4-$6 USD

Hotel room with ocean view: $80-$120 USD / Night

Now that you know what to bring, what to leave, and how much you can expect to spend during your trip, let‚Äôs get into what to prepare for when driving down there (the preferred method).

The Realities Of Driving In Baja California, Mexico

There‚Äôs only been one occasion where I did NOT drive my car into Mexico. It was my first solo trip to Baja and to be ‚Äúsafe‚Äù I thought it would be smart to catch a taxi in Tijuana‚Ä¶ Big mistake.

As soon as I walked across the border I waved down a beat-up, rusty taxi that squealed aggressively until it came to a stop. As I opened the door I noticed the dash was lit up like a Christmas tree with every caution light on imaginable.

The driver introduced himself as ‚ÄúPinche‚Äù and seemed like a nice guy but it wasn‚Äôt until AFTER I buckled my seatbelt that I realized this man had only one arm. But get this, the arm he did have only had a thumb and a pinky left‚Ä¶ a permanent shaka one could say ü§ôüèΩ

I was speechless, in utter disbelief that someone like this could be a taxi driver. But it gets better.

Pinche begins driving with his knee and using his stoked-out claw to shift gears because‚Ä¶ well, the car was also a stick shift.

At this point, I‚Äôm in the passenger seat losing my fucking mind as I watched this guy navigate the hectic traffic of downtown Tijuana. Just when I think this couldn‚Äôt get any worse, his phone starts ringing.

PINCHE ANSWERS HIS PHONE!

With his cell phone pinched between his cheek and shoulder, driving with his knee, changing gears with a semi-intact left arm, in a car that looked like it was purchased off the Taliban, I came to the realization that I wasn‚Äôt in San Diego anymore.

He must have recognized that I was freaking out because he diverted from his fast-paced conversation to hand me a cigarette. I politely put the cigarette in my shirt pocket but he INSISTED that I smoke it in the car and as he pointed to the dashboard he murmurs, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Honda‚Äù.

As I inhaled the final draws from what was probably the first cigarette of my life we took the Rosarito exit. With only a couple blocks left of our journey, I made the decision right then and there that if I made it out of that car alive, moving forward I‚Äôll drive myself to Mexico.

But before I got out of the car I thought to ask for his business card. Just in case a friend needed a ride while in Baja I figured it would be hilarious if I recommend they call this guy only for them to find out that he only has two fingers and drives a manual.

If you ever meet El Pinche, tell him Justin sent you.

If you decide to drive yourself, you‚Äôll find it‚Äôs not that different than driving in the United States. Any competent driver should be able to handle it on their own; it‚Äôs even easier with a friend in the passenger seat to help navigate.

Mexico has cleaned up its act in recent years. There are still some gnarly potholes every once in a while that you want to keep an eye out for but compared to how it used to be, the roads are much better.

Especially once you get closer to Rosarito what you NEED to be paying attention to are the ‚ÄúAlto‚Äù (Stop) signs. For some reason, they‚Äôre way smaller than the stop signs in the U.S. and sometimes it‚Äôs just spray-painted on the pavement.

Half of the locals just blow through them anyways and I‚Äôve ran through my fair share on accident but be careful at night because they‚Äôre hard to spot and cops use this as an excuse to give tourists a hard time.

For some reason, people are surprised to find out that some Mexicans have a lot of money too. Especially in the past couple years around Tijuana and Rosarito it‚Äôs become super common to see nice cars while venturing down south.

You‚Äôll also notice that half of the license plates you see will read California. If you‚Äôre worried about standing out and drawing unnecessary attention to yourself, for the most part don‚Äôt be. Any car that blends in when in SoCal should be fine in the northern most sections Baja. That is, if you stick to the right areas.

Once you get south of Ensenada you hit the final frontier. Dirt roads, small fishing towns, poorer populations, less people, empty roadways, and less oversight to crime. Driving a nice rig with a foreign license plate can sometimes draw the wrong attention. Finding yourself in the wrong place at the wrong time can become reality down here. Diehard surf travelers like myself are starting to question if the risk is worth the reward anymore.

My goal is to eliminate your fears and provide knowledge that will help you cultivate an epic Baja experience. The last thing I want to do is spread ‚Äúhorror stories‚Äù but also, we can‚Äôt ignore reality. The dangers over there (can be) VERY REAL.

I‚Äôm not saying EVERY law enforcement officer in Mexico is shady‚Ä¶ Nowadays in all honestly, most of them probably aren‚Äôt. But I‚Äôve had a fair share of negative experiences.

In the event you encounter a corrupt police officer or even an honest one for that matter, it‚Äôs important to know how to handle yourself.

The following story is by far the worst encounter I‚Äôve ever had when it comes to police in Mexico. I want to walk you through my experience because it highlights many of the things you should NOT do when encountering police in Mexico.

Now it‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve thought about this but for the sake of education let‚Äôs get into my war story‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs right, I said TAKE ME TO JAIL!‚Äù

What I am about to tell you occurred AFTER my time with Cecilia. Thanks to her I had some knowledge under my belt but even then, some lessons must be learned the hard way.

It was 3:00 am on a Saturday and I‚Äôm driving my friend back to our hotel after picking him up from a night out in Rosarito (Mistake #1).

My car at the time was a ran down Mazda 3, a perfect car for the Mexican roads. The only issue was that it had Washington State license plates (Mistake #2).

I pulled onto a main street about a mile down the road from Papas and Beer when we got lit up by a police truck. It was so immediate that I knew we were in for something bad.

Having a rough idea of what was in store, I told my friend to be quiet and let me do the talking. We pull to the side of the road and before the officer could get to my door I tell my friend to take the cards out of his wallet and hide them under his seat. I did the same (Lesson #1).

When the dark silhouette reached my window I already had everything prepared as if I was getting pulled over in the States. All the interior lights were on, the keys were on the dashboard along with my ID, and my hands were on the steering wheel.

However, when his face came into view I immediately knew something was off. Here walked a gentleman in his late 40s, wearing an Under Armor hoodie, no identification, no badge, no firearm or gear, really nothing at all that insinuated that he was a police officer for that matter, and I quickly learned he didn‚Äôt speak English.

I vividly remember thinking to myself ‚ÄúOh this is going to be easy‚Äù. A rather arrogant mindset to have going into a situation like this (Mistake #3).

For a moment the ‚Äúofficer‚Äù just stood there in silence shifting his stare from me to my friend and then back to me. It seemed pretty clear that he was sizing us up so I gave him a look that said ‚Äúis there a problem?‚Äù.

With a slight hesitation he reached with his finger and in the dust on my side mirror he wrote ‚Äú500‚Äù.

This has to be a fucking joke, I thought to myself. He didn‚Äôt even say anything!

My friend looked confused but I knew exactly what this guy meant.

With a tone of disbelief, I quickly said ‚ÄúWhat!? No.‚Äù

I could tell this threw him on his heels and before he could say anything I said ‚ÄúLook, I don‚Äôt even have $500‚Äù.

As I pointed to the wallet on the dashboard the words ‚Äúfive hundred‚Äù came out of his mouth. He spoke broken English but his tone was firm.

The following is word for word how the rest of the conversation went down.

Me: ‚ÄúWhat did I do?‚Äù

Officer: ‚ÄúYou drunk.‚Äù

Me: ‚ÄúNo I‚Äôm not!‚Äù

Officer: ‚ÄúYou speeding.‚Äù

Me: ‚ÄúDude, you pulled me over before I could even reach the speed limit.‚Äù

Officer: ‚ÄúYou no stop at stop sign‚Äù

Me: ‚ÄúThen write me a ticket or take me to jail.‚Äù

Officer: ‚ÄúOkay, I take you to jail.‚Äù

The officer and I are responding to each other almost instantly, we‚Äôre only about thirty seconds into the interaction at this point. The energy was super tense and I started to get the feeling that neither myself nor the officer knew how this was going to play out.

The officer continued to stand there for a couple seconds (which felt like 15 minutes) until I repeated ‚ÄúThen take me to jail‚Äù, essentially calling his bluff (Lesson #2).

Without speaking the officer took my wallet and signaled for my friend to give him his. Then with both wallets in hand, he walked back to the truck.

My friend remained silent in the passenger seat and when the officer was out of ears length I said to him ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry dude, this guy isn‚Äôt taking us to jail. He‚Äôs going to take the cash in our wallets and let us go.‚Äù.

I couldn‚Äôt help but think the last thing this officer probably expected that night was to encounter an eighteen-year-old surfer requesting to be taken to jail.

About five minutes passed and I began to wonder what is taking so long. Figuring that he‚Äôs had plenty of time to ransack our wallets by now, I assume the officer is contemplating how to handle the situation he just got himself into.

At this point, I start considering that taking the spare cash in our wallets might not be the end of what this guy had planned for us.

I tell my friend to stay cool and try to record what happens when the officer comes back. My friend says ‚Äúokay‚Äù and grabs my phone from the cup holder (Mistake #4 and this one quite frankly could have gotten us fucking killed).

Another couple minutes go by before I notice the officer was walking back to my car. As he gets closer and I‚Äôm able to make him out I realize this is a completely different person.

A much larger guy in full police uniform, carrying a Beretta ARX160 comes to the window and with a loud aggressive voice yells ‚ÄúOkay!‚Äù

I could tell he was going to say more but as soon as he saw us he stopped mid-sentence and immediately took three steps back and out of view.

I look over to my drunk friend and realize the flash is turned on with my cell phone camera.

‚ÄúFuck. Put the phone away‚Äù I tell him.

He tucks my phone beneath the seat but before he can get his arm back the passenger door rips open. I notice the original officer is back and he‚Äôs reached into the car and already had both hands on my friend‚Äôs shoulder.

I watch as my friend gets pulled out of the car, seatbelt still on. My fight or flight responses kick in and my heart starts racing. Expecting the same treatment I reach down and undo my seatbelt to make things easier.

A split second goes by and my car door rips open. Without making any rapid movements I put both of my hands up to signal I am not a threat. The uniformed officer reaches in and pulls me out of the car.

Just as I‚Äôm thinking ‚ÄúOkay nice, he‚Äôs not beating the shit out of me‚Äù I get slammed down HARD on the front of the hood. He didn‚Äôt even handcuff me so I just awkwardly stood there still while he started rummaging through my pockets.

He starts pulling things out like my chapstick and loose change, only to briefly look at them before throwing them into the street. I felt like a prisoner of war that has been taken captive.

Out of the corner of my eye, I see my friend face down on the pavement receiving similar treatment. The officer finishes his search and grabs a handful of my junk in what seemed like an effort to intimidate me.

Then something funny happened. Without saying a word, both officers walked back to the truck, flipped a U-turn, and drove in the other direction.

‚ÄúWhat the fuck was that!?‚Äù my friend said as he picked himself up off the street.

‚ÄúYou good?‚Äù I asked.

‚ÄúYeah, I‚Äôm alright‚Ä¶‚Äù He relied.

I patted myself down to see what belongings I still had and gathered my things from the street. They took the money out of our wallets but didn‚Äôt find the extra cash, and credit cards under the floor mat.

We reviewed the footage on my phone and when my friend went to send the video to himself he came to the grim realization that the Under Armor officer stole his phone.

Understandably, the officer was probably thinking it would be a good idea to steal the phone to clear any incriminating evidence against himself. However, my phone, the one that was used to capture the video was hidden out of sight under the seat.

Here‚Äôs what I assumed happened: The legitimate officer and his street criminal cousin were paroling the streets looking for unsuspecting tourists or victims. After realizing I wasn‚Äôt here to play their game they came back intending to give us our wallets (minus small bills) and were probably going to yell/intimidate me for effectively calling them on their bullshit. After this, they were more than likely just going to cut us loose.

HOWEVER, the flash on my camera signifying that they were being recorded massively (and unnecessarily) intensified the interaction, forcing them to steal our phones and whatever else in order to cover up their tracks.

For years I had that video saved on my phone. From time to time I would show it to friends but for the most part, it just sat in my camera roll collecting dust. I spent hours searching through my computer for it with no luck. If I find it down the line I‚Äôll upload it to this article.

Mistakes and Lessons

I‚Äôm not proud of how I handled the situation. I like to think that if it happened again today, It would be a much quicker, way less problematic interaction. There are plenty of things I did wrong and there‚Äôs a few things I did right. Let‚Äôs go down the list.

Mistake #1

Yes, I was completely sober. Also, our hotel was only 5 minutes from where we were. Still, I should NOT have been on the road at that time of night.

Driving before light to a surf spot or after dark for a couple of hours to get back to the border isn‚Äôt as big of a deal. However, being out between the hours of midnight and four in the morning can be bad news no matter where you‚Äôre at, especially if you‚Äôre in Mexico.

If you desperately need a ride after dark, it‚Äôs best practice to get yourself a taxi. Preferably driven by a man with two arms. If there‚Äôs not a taxi within eyesight a good tip is to ask your server, bartender, or hotel worker.

Pro Tip: The local community is pretty tight and everyone seems to have the phone number of a nice person who‚Äôs down to help you out for a few bucks. There‚Äôs also almost always a taxi driver hanging near by, even if you don‚Äôt see him.

Mistake #2

Normally I would say having U.S. license plates that aren‚Äôt ‚ÄúCalifornia‚Äù is fine but coupled with driving at 3 am I was just a rolling hunk of meat ready for the taking.

If you have non-California plates and you don‚Äôt want to draw unnecessary attention to yourself the rule of thumb is obvious: don‚Äôt be the only one on the road.

PS. I still have Washington plates. I‚Äôve since traveled with Washington plates at least sixty times and have had zero issues.

Mistake #3

I went into the situation with confidence which is fine however, my nonchalant attitude threw the first officer off. When dealing with the police in Baja it‚Äôs important to be knowledgeable but at the same time let them feel like they are still in control of the situation. The last thing you want to do is take a shot at, or challenge their ego.

The FBI negotiator Chris Voss says ‚ÄúThe art of negotiation is letting the other person have your way‚Äù. If I would have just explained to the first officer that I don‚Äôt have $500 and I knew I wasn‚Äôt doing anything wrong, I probably would have been fine just paying him a $10 ‚Äútoll‚Äù or ‚Äúgringo tax‚Äù to let us be on our way.

Mistake #4

Telling my friend to record was just plain stupid. I truly believe if I would have just avoided this, everything would have been fine.

Many law enforcement officers go to extreme lengths to conceal their identities. Almost all military personnel, but many police officers as well wear facial coverings even in the blistering heat of summer.

I assume this is to avoid being recognized and not to keep their neck warm or look cool.

Putting a camera in an officer‚Äôs face like you‚Äôre at a protest in downtown Portland isn‚Äôt going to go over well when in Mexico. Simply don‚Äôt do it.

Lesson #1

In this situation, hiding our cash and credit cards saved us hundreds of dollars, possibly thousands if the officers would have found the debit cards and decided to escort us to the closest ATM (Which I‚Äôve heard has happened).

Nowadays when in Baja I keep $40 and maybe a credit card in my wallet max. If I ever face a situation again where my life is in danger or I‚Äôm being robbed, my strategy will be to hand them my entire wallet and act both dumb and scared.

The idea here is for them to leave thinking they just robbed you blind but you‚Äôre still able to carry on with your day with a slightly less net worth.

Lesson #2

Almost everyone that has ever heard this story thinks I‚Äôm clinically insane for telling the officer to take me to jail. Understandable‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs super important to understand how the scam works if you want to avoid being the victim.

Extortion is wrong. Yes, even in Mexico. If a police officer refuses to take a small bribe and tries to further extort you for something blatantly false, requesting them to write you a ticket or take you to jail can be the ultimate chess move if said with the right tone.

Requesting that they write you a ticket or take you to jail is a great response because they generally can‚Äôt do either of those things.

Remember, the officer is simply looking for money. Whatever he can get. Writing you a ticket that is only payable to the government serves no purpose in supporting his weekend beer fund.

Also, how would the officer even explain to higher-ups why he‚Äôs bringing an American into the station? And even once you‚Äôre there, it does nothing for him but waste time and raise red flags among his non-corrupt peers.

Finally, it allows you to call their bluff without being confrontational. When they give you the famous line ‚ÄúNo ticket, you need to just pay me now‚Äù, that‚Äôs when you show them your wallet with just $10 or so in there (remember to leave your cards out).

At this point, they‚Äôll hopefully take the decoy cash and have you carry on with your day. Meanwhile, you just avoided a huge hassle while the rest of your cash and credit cards remain safely hidden.

I know this may seem like a lot to take in‚Ä¶ So please remember, if you‚Äôre not out looking for trouble like I was, the odds of you experiencing something like this are very low.

As much as I‚Äôd love to say yes, the real answer is it depends. The more rural you go generally the safer and more friendly it gets but also being close to town offers the security of witnesses. Most people assume ‚Äúthe cartels kill everyone with no discretion‚Äù. This thought process (although understandable) is simply untrue. We kind of got into this earlier, but no one wants to kill you. And DEFINITELY don‚Äôt do it if you‚Äôre driving a nice car or truck. ‚ÄúCheckpoints‚Äù and ‚Äútoll booths‚Äù are sometimes set up by armed bandits and local cartels on dark, lonely Mexican roads. If you make the mistake of ignoring this rule and you encounter a checkpoint don‚Äôt panic or run off, typically you can pay them whatever cash you have and you‚Äôll be on your way.

Also, don‚Äôt be afraid to negotiate. Haggling is expected and you can usually knock the price down by staying polite and reasonable. Welcome to the gringo tax. I‚Äôve said it once, I‚Äôve said it twice, and I‚Äôll say it again; the cartel doesn‚Äôt want to kill you and the bandits just want your money. How To Cross back Into The U.S From Mexico

After a few epic hours, or even a few epic days in Mexico you‚Äôll eventually reach a point where you point your sails north and head back home.

But just when you think the adventure is over, one must realize they now need to cross the busiest border in the modern world.

I won‚Äôt sugarcoat it, crossing back into the U.S. through the San Ysidro Port of Entry can be a serious pain in the ass. Getting stuck in line can be a living nightmare and I wouldn‚Äôt wish it on my worst enemy. Unless you time the drive perfectly, you‚Äôre more than likely going to be waiting for a minimum of two hours.

This being said, there are measures you can take that will ease your border crossing experience.

Many people check the U.S customs website to view the wait times but similar to the apps we use to check the surf conditions, the information can be hit or miss.

I operate on the following rule of thumb that has served me well so far; I don‚Äôt even consider heading back to the U.S. until at least 9 pm. During the late evening traffic dies down. If you can go even later, I would recommend doing so.

I‚Äôve made it work crossing back around 8 pm, you‚Äôll endure a two ‚Äì three and a half hour wait, but should make it home before midnight. On the other hand, I‚Äôve also crossed back as late as 1 am ‚Äì 3 am and waited only fifteen minutes (I know this contradicts previous safety protocols we discussed).

Pulling an all-nighter to make it home certainly isn‚Äôt the only way to go but the later you can push it, the better off you‚Äôll be.

If you‚Äôre a morning person, I‚Äôd recommend staying the night and crossing back the next morning before 8 am. Beware, during the week a lot of Mexicans commute to the United States for work so crossing in the morning could be a nightmare.

If you‚Äôre traveling on the weekend and can make it to the border between 5 am -7 am you should be okay.

Directions

Two lanes that exist when traveling back to the United States. There‚Äôs the global entry / ready lane which is used by everyone.

There‚Äôs also the Sentri / Fast Pass lane that requires additional documentation and membership status that can be acquired through an application.

Differentiating between these two lanes can be pretty difficult and even with a bunch of experience driving back and forth I‚Äôve still found myself getting stuck in the wrong lane. Avoid doing this at all costs!

Accidentally finding yourself in the Sentri lane can bring about some serious consequences if faced with the wrong border patrol agent. You‚Äôre going to be dealing with an American when passing through the border on your way out so bribing your way out of trouble is out of the question, don‚Äôt even joke about it‚Ä¶ Trust me, they don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs funny.

Supposedly you can be fined up to $5,000 or even $10,000 if repeated a second time.

Personally, I‚Äôve gone through the sentri lane on two separate occasions. I was immediately apologetic and took every measure possible to kiss the ass of the border patrol agent taking my information. Thankfully both times I was let off with a simple warning however, this is a massive roll of the dice and I wouldn‚Äôt recommend testing your luck.

You‚Äôd think that with a fine so significant, they would do a better job labeling the two lanes but in reality, it‚Äôs genuinely pretty difficult to find your way. If there‚Äôs any sort of insight I can share with this it‚Äôs to be cautious about trusting google maps; it does a good job getting you to where you roughly need to be however, it specializes in choosing the quickest available option which is almost always via the sentri lane.

Once you reach downtown Tijuana you will start to see signs directing you towards ‚ÄúSan Diego‚Äù and ‚ÄúI5‚Äù, when you see these I recommend aborting the GPS and following the road signs like the good ol‚Äô days. On this point, if you get overwhelmed do not be afraid to circle a few times and give it multiple attempts.

You‚Äôll know what I‚Äôm talking about when you get there‚Ä¶ The exits come up fast and it‚Äôs easy to get turned around. If you end up making it in the right line within the first five tries I would say you did a decent job as a newbie.
